Building multimodal AI that sees, reasons, and communicates with data

Established in 2019 at York University, our lab bridges Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Information Visualization (Vis)—two domains that have historically evolved separately—to advance language-based data interaction and reasoning that is more accessible, inclusive, and intelligent.

RESEARCH THEMES

Multimodal LLMs for Visualization Understanding and Generation

Benchmarks and models for chart comprehension, narrative generation, and visual data communication—shaping how multimodal LLMs interpret, explain, and generate visualizations from and for real analytic workflows.

Representative papers

  • Text2Vis: Generating Multimodal Visualizations from Natural Language (EMNLP 2025)
  • DataNarrative: Automated data-driven storytelling with visualizations and texts (EMNLP 2024)
  • ChartGemma: Visual instruction-tuning for chart reasoning in the wild (COLING 2025)
  • ChartQA: A benchmark for question answering about charts with visual and logical reasoning (ACL 2022)
  • Chart-to-Text: A Large-Scale Benchmark for Chart Summarization (ACL 2022)
  • BigCharts-R1: Visual Reinforcement Learning for Chart Reasoning (COLM 2025)

Agentic AI for Analytic Workflows

Building multimodal agents that plan actions, interact with analytic tools, refine outputs, and collaborate with humans across realistic, end-to-end data workflows.

Representative papers

  • DashboardQA: Benchmarking Multimodal Agents for Interactive Dashboards (2025)
  • Text2Vis: Agentic Refinement for Visualization Generation via an Actor–Critic Framework (EMNLP 2025)
  • DataNarrative: Narrative Construction via Multi-Agent Planner–Evaluator Systems (EMNLP 2024)

Accessible, Inclusive & Responsible VLMs for Visualization

Ensuring analytic AI systems are fair, transparent, robust to deceptive designs, and supportive of users with diverse abilities, literacy levels, and cultural backgrounds.

Representative papers

  • SeeChart: Accessible Visualizations for Blind and Low-Vision Users (IUI 2023)
  • DeceptionVis: The Perils of Chart Deception for Vision-Language Models (IEEE VIS 2025 — Best Paper)
  • From Charts to Fair Narratives: Uncovering Geo-Economic Bias in Chart-to-Text (EMNLP 2025)
  • Judging the Judges: Reliability of VLMs as Chart Reasoning Evaluators (ACL 2025, Industry Track)

Human-AI Alignment for Co-Creative Data Intelligence

Designing generative analytic interfaces and collaboration modes that align AI reasoning with human goals, critique, and creativity in real data analysis settings.

Representative papers

  • Sneak Pique: Autocompletion as a Data Discovery Scaffold (UIST 2020)
  • evizeon: Applying Pragmatics Principles for Visual Analytics Interaction (TVCG 2017)

Language Understanding, Summarization, and Evaluation

Advancing question answering, summarization, domain adaptation, and trustworthy evaluation methods that strengthen the foundations of language-driven analytics.

Representative papers

  • A Systematic Survey and Critical Review on Evaluating Large Language Models (EMNLP 2024)
  • Improving Automatic Evaluation of LLMs in Biomedical Relation Extraction via LLMs-as-the-Judge (ACL 2025)
  • Open-RAG: Enhanced Retrieval-Augmented Reasoning with Open-Source LLMs (EMNLP 2024)
  • Domain Adaptation with Pre-Trained Transformers for Query-Focused Abstractive Text Summarization (Computational Linguistics 2022)
